mentions.context: RAMP enables us to easily compare and reproduce predictive experiments.
A RAMP "starting kit " is a placeholder where we define the data-science problem: we provide the datasets, the metric, and the model validation technique.
The RAMP website was used to evaluate the solutions of the participants (i.e., predictive models): participants submit their code and the website trains (fits) and evaluates them.
Challenge platform: RAMP is an online data science tool used to organise challenges.
For this purpose, we used the RAMP (Rapid Analytics and Model Prototyping) workbench.
For this purpose, we used the RAMP (Rapid Analytics and Model Prototyping) workbench.
Participants were free to use any Python library to build their machine learning model.
Participants submitted their solutions on the RAMP website ( https://ramp.studio
Anatomical MRI: Anatomical MRI was preprocessed and segmented using FreeSurfer v6.0.
To derive these individual measurements, the data were processed with standard neuroimaging tools: Freesurfer ( Fischl et al., 1999 ), FSL ( Woolrich et al., 2009 ), and AFNI ( Cox, 1996 ).

Data and code availability: The public data, the code of the ten best submissions, the MRI preprocessing scripts and the scripts used to generate the figures are available at https://github.com/neuroa natomy/autism-challenge .

Data and code availability: The public data, the code of the ten best submissions, the MRI preprocessing scripts and the scripts used to generate the figures are available at https://github.com/neuroa natomy/autism-challenge .
To derive these individual measurements, the data were processed with standard neuroimaging tools: Freesurfer ( Fischl et al., 1999 ), FSL ( Woolrich et al., 2009 ), and AFNI ( Cox, 1996 ).
To derive these individual measurements, the data were processed with standard neuroimaging tools: Freesurfer ( Fischl et al., 1999 ), FSL ( Woolrich et al., 2009 ), and AFNI ( Cox, 1996 ).

We extracted three kinds of anatomical features: (i) mean regional cortical thickness, (ii) cortical surface area of regions parcellated with the Desikan-Killiany Atlas ( Desikan et al., 2006 ), and (iii) volumes of subcortical regions segmented with the FreeSurfer atlas ( Fischl et al., 2002 ).
